title.narrative: Ethiopia Tigray Joint Response (ETJR)

description.narrative:
Since the conflict between a federal military force and the Tigray People’s Liberation Front (TPLF), thousands of people’s lives has been impacted and worsening the already poor humanitarian situation. At least 222,413 people are internally displaced as a result of the conflict, while 58,334 people have fled into neighboring Sudan (UNHCR, 2020). Additionally, at least 63,000 have been displaced within Amhara and Afar (UNICEF, 2021). According to the Emergency Coordination Center (ECC) 4,5 million people need direct food assistance as a result of insecurity on imports and the harvest. Before the conflict started, a total of 507,000 already received food assistance.
Two months since the start of the conflict in Tigray, the humanitarian situation continues to critically deteriorate. Dire shortages of the most basic supplies, including food, water, fuel and cash affect the whole region, leading to a looming humanitarian catastrophe. With access to water, sanitation & health services seriously disrupted, humanitarians warned about the heightened risk of water-borne & vector-borne diseases, as well as COVID-19. The situation in and around the four refugee camps, which together host 96,000 refugees, is absolutely dire. Many people, including 5 NGO staff members, were killed during the horrific atrocities that took place during attacks (UN OCHA, 2021). Despite declaring the completion of the war, fighting continues and the situation in Tigray remains extremely volatile. Sporadic fighting in rural areas is reported on a weekly and sometimes even daily basis. The security situation is dire, especially in peripheral areas and villages around Mekelle, where looting and other incidents are still occurring. Despite the challenging security environment, humanitarians continue to deliver limited assistance with available resources and in the limited areas where access is relatively permissive.
Provide life-saving assistance to people facing severe acute needs.

A total of 3,778 beneficairies will receive food and Shelter supports by the two local partners(EOC-DICAC and Caritas Ethiopia). 2000 people will be supported food items and 1,778 people will get Shelter Items(NFIs). All partners and their local implementing partners have agreed to follow the same five guiding rules for beneficiary selection and targeting.
Beneficiaries are selected through involvement of local government, community elders and partners, selecting the most vulnerable through agreed criteria. Selection criteria of most vulnerable are in line with cluster guidelines and include: - Female Headed Household; - Child Headed Household; - Disabled Headed Household; - Elderly Headed Household with no adults having an income;

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

description.narrative: Project Agreement
60% 1st Cash transfer to Caritas Eth
60% 1st Cash transfer to DICAC

receiver-org.narrative: Development and Inter-Church Aid Commission - Ethiopian Orthodox Church

description.narrative: Commitment

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: Individual household shelter
SHL-I1: Number of people having access to basic, safe and dignified shelters solutions

description.narrative: Basic, safe and dignified: - affected individuals have an minimum covered floor area of 3.5m2 per person. - all shelter solutions and materials meet locally agreed technical and performance standards and are culturally acceptable. - all household (re-)construction is in accordance with safe building practices and standards. - all household (re-)construction demonstrate involvement of the affected population and/or are culturally acceptable by the affected population.

title.narrative: Non-food items
SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).

title.narrative: Localisation
LOC-I1: % of budget that went to national and local actors
Capacity Building (reach)
LOC-I3: Number of national and local actors supported with capacity-building

description.narrative: Total number of national and local actors that received capacity-building support during implementation. In case more than one individual from a national/local actor participate in the capacity building activities. Note that this does not include local offices of INGOs.

title.narrative: Empowerment
Number of local partner organizations that are engaged in equitable partnerships with Cordaid

description.narrative: Number of partnerships scoring a total of 3 and above when using the Power Awareness Tool, which Cordaid uses for partnerships with local partner organisations (with budget above 500'000Euro) at the start, in monitoring and end of the projects

title.narrative: Saving Lives Corporate Indicators
Number of beneficiaries reached (SL)

description.narrative: Number of people who benefitted directly or indirectly with life-saving humanitarian assistance and/or resilient recovery services and/or disaster preparedness from activities in a humanitarian response implemented by Cordaid and implementing partners

title.narrative: Number of local organisations strengthened in Emergency preparedness and Response

description.narrative: Number of local organisations strengthened in Emergency preparedness and Response by Cordaid and/or implementing partners whereby a strengthened organisation refers to one that is better prepared and able to respond to a crisis based on assessments made in the PRA.

title.narrative: FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

title.narrative: SHL-I4: Number of people provided with non-food items (other than hygiene/dignity kits)

description.narrative: Distribution of Non-Food Items. All household materials excluding those that fall under hygiene/dignity kits or direct shelter items. Also excludes unrestricted cash, which is to be put under indicator CSH-I1 or CSH-I2. However, if cash is provided for the purpose of buying household items, it should be put under this indicator (i.e. restricted cash).
